content:
###Graphing points in the coordinate plane

Points in the coordinate plane are identified by coordinates given in the form $(\blueD{x},\greenD{y})$.



[[☃ image 1]]

The $x$-coordinate represents a value on the$\blueD{\text{ horizontal}}$ axis.   
The $y$-coordinate represents a value on the $\greenD{\text{vertical}}$ axis.

**Example:**

Plot the point $(6, 4)$.

For $( \blueD{6}, \greenD{4})$ our $x$-coordinate is $\blueD6$, and our $y$-coordinate is $\greenD4$.

Let's start by going right to $\blueD{6}$ on the $x$-axis:



[[☃ image 2]]

Now we go up to $\greenD4$ on the $y$-axis, and plot the point $(\blueD{6}, \greenD{4})$:



[[☃ image 3]]



*Want to learn more about graphing points?  Check out [this video](/v/graphing-points-exercise).*

*Want to learn about negative graphing points, too?  Check out [this article](/a/graphing-coordinates-review).*

options.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 9 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A blue arrow moves right along the x-axis. A green arrow moves up along the y-axis.
A coordinate grid. The x-axis is labeled 1 to 9. The y-axis is labeled 1 to 9. A blue arrow moves right along the x-axis from the origin to the 6.

A coordinate grid. The x-axis is labeled 1 to 9. The y-axis is labeled 1 to 9. A blue arrow moves right along the x-axis from the origin to the 6. A green arrow moves up 4 units from the 6 on the x-axis to align with 4 on the y-axis. A point labeled (6,4) is plotted at the end of the green arrow.

hint.content:
Coordinates are listed as $(\blueD{x},\greenD{y})$.

So, for $( \blueD{1}, \greenD{5})$ our $x$-coordinate is $\blueD1$, and our $y$-coordinate is $\greenD5$.

Let's start by going to $\blueD{1}$ on the $x$-axis:



[[☃ image 1]]

Now we go up to $\greenD5$ on the $y$-axis, and plot the point $( \blueD{1}, \greenD{5})$:



[[☃ image 2]]

The answer



[[☃ image 3]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid. The x-axis is labeled 1 to 9. The y-axis is labeled 1 to 9. A blue arrow moves right along the x-axis from the origin to the 1.

A coordinate grid. The x-axis is labeled 1 to 9. The y-axis is labeled 1 to 9. A blue arrow moves right along the x-axis from the origin to the 1. A green arrow moves up 5 units from the 1 on the x-axis to align with 5 on the y-axis. A point labeled (1,5) is plotted at the end of the green arrow.
A coordinate grid shows the ordered pair (1,5) plotted 1 unit to the right and 5 units up from the origin.

A coordinate grid shows the ordered pair (2,4) plotted 2 units to the right and 8 units up from the origin.

content:
##Identifying points

To determine the coordinates (or ordered pair) of a given point, we need to count the $\blueD{\text{horizontal}}$ and $\greenD{\text{vertical}}$ distance of the point from the $\redD{\text{origin (0, 0)}}$.



[[☃ image 1]]

**Example:**

Use the following coordinate plane to determine the ordered pair for the given point.



[[☃ image 2]]



Let's start by counting the distance from $(0, 0)$ to the given point on the $x$-axis:


[[☃ image 3]]

The point is $\blueD3$ units to the right of the origin.

Now let's count the distance from $(0, 0)$ to the given point on the $y$-axis:


[[☃ image 4]]

The point is $\greenD1$ unit above the origin.

The coordinates of the point are $(\blueD3, \greenD1)$.

options.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A blue arrow moves right along the x-axis. A green arrow moves up along the y-axis. There is a red point at the origin. A point is plotted 3 units to the right and 1 unit up from the origin.
A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A point is plotted 3 units to the right and 1 unit up from the origin.

A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A point is plotted 3 units to the right and 1 unit up from the origin. A blue arrow moves right along the x-axis from the origin to the 3.

A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A point is plotted 3 units to the right and 1 unit up from the origin. A green arrow moves up 1 unit from the 3 on the x-axis to align with the 1 on the y-axis.

##Practice set 2: Identifying points

[[☃ graded-group-set 1]]

*Want to try more problems like this? Check out these exercises:*
[Identify coordinates](e/identify-coordinates)  
[Identify points](e/identifying-points)

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2A
gradedGroups.content:
**What is the *x*-coordinate of the point plotted below?** 

[[☃ numeric-input 1]]



[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A point is plotted 4 units to the right and 3 units up from the origin.

hint.content:
The *x*-coordinate tells us how far we move right from the origin.


[[☃ image 1]]

The point is $4$ units to the right of the origin.

**The *x*-coordinate is $4$.**

options.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. A point is plotted 4 units to the right and 3 units up from the origin. A blue arrow moves right 4 units from the 3 on the y-axis to above the 4 on the x-axis.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2B
gradedGroups.content:
**Use the following coordinate plane to write the ordered pair for each point.** 



[[☃ image 1]]

Point | Ordered pair
- | - 
$\greenD{A}$ | $($ [[☃ numeric-input 1]] , [[☃ numeric-input 2]] $)$
$\purpleC{B}$| $($ [[☃ numeric-input 3]] , [[☃ numeric-input 4]] $)$
$\blueD{C}$| $($ [[☃ numeric-input 5]] , [[☃ numeric-input 6]] $)$

options.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. Three plot points are on different parts of the grid. Point A is 1 unit to the right and 6 units up from the origin. Point B is 2 units to the right from the origin on the x-axis. Point C is 6 units to the right and 6 units up from the origin.

hint.content:
To get to point $\greenD{A}$ from the origin $(0,0)$, we move right to $\greenD{1}$ and up to $\greenD{6}$.


To get to point $\purpleC{B}$ from the origin  $(0,0)$, we move right to $\purpleC{2}$ and up $\purpleC{0}$.


To get to point $\blueD{C}$ from the origin  $(0,0)$, we move right to $\blueD{6}$ and up to $\blueD{6}$.


[[☃ image 1]]

Point | Ordered pair
- | - 
$\greenD{A}$ | $\greenD{(1,6)}$
$\purpleC{B}$| $\purpleC{(2,0)}$
$\blueD{C}$| $\blueD{(6,6)}$

options.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. Three plot points are on different parts of the grid. A green arrow moves right from the origin to the 1 on the x-axis. Another green arrow moves up 6 units from the 1 on the x-axis to align with the 6 on the y-axis. Point A appears at the end of this arrow. A purple arrow moves right from the origin to the 2 on the x-axis. Point B appears at the end of the purple arrow. A blue arrow moves right from the origin to the 6 on the x-axis. Another blue arrow moves up 6 arrows from the 6 on the x-axis to align with the 6 on the y-axis. Point C appears at the end of this arrow.

gradedGroups.title: Problem 2C
gradedGroups.content:
**Which ordered pair is *not* graphed below?**


[[☃ image 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. Three plot points are on different parts of the grid. From left to right the first plot point is 6 units up from the origin on the y-axis. The second plot point is 2 units to the right and 6 units up from the origin. The last plot point is 6 units to the right and 2 units up from the origin.

hint.content:
Let's label the graphed points.



[[☃ image 2]]

**$\redC{(0,2)}$ was not graphed.  
$$**



[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A coordinate grid is labeled 0 to 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. Four plot points are on different parts of the grid. From left to right the first plot point represents the ordered pair (0,2). The second plot point represents the ordered pair (0,6). The third plot point represents the ordered pair (2,6). The last plot point represents the ordered pair (6,2).

A coordinate grid is labeled 0 through 6 on the x-axis and the y-axis. Three plot points are on different parts of the grid. From left to right the first plot point represents the ordered pair (0,6). The second plot represents the ordered pair (2,6). The third plot point represents the ordered pair (6,2).
